DrD
I tried to include every possible answer but, I'm sure I didn't. After you respond, let's have your opinion.

post_info.post_title: POLL: Your opinion about "filth" on radio and TV and why?

Robbie
I think it should be cleaned up.
Broker

Don't mind cable... but I do mind network TV. Networks are getting use of the public airwaves to broadcast... they have the responsibility to deliver good programming to the people. I don't care what they do with a cable network though.
step314

It seems to me that what we need is not less nudity but more thoughtful, clean nudity. Similarly, there is basically just a certain type of violence that is harmful. 
 
 Take Britney Spears, for instance. Her first video was fairly sexy in a fairly clean way, so she deservedly became popular. All she had to do to remain popular was to wear sexy clothes, sing a little, and stay fairly clean looking. She couldn't do the last part, and so she is less popular now. 
 
 I often find myself surprised at how dumb the media is in portraying sex. All they would have to do to produce sexy shows is to put on the screen pretty, clean, affectionate girls in sexy bikinis (or less). But nooooo, they forever have to make affectionate girls and women dirty-looking and screwed-up. There is nothing wrong with nudity. Obviously attractive females are much more appealing and interesting to men if they are nude. But on cable, when a female is nude, you can pretty much expect her to be sleezy-looking and that it is just a short time before she has sex or sodomy with some galoot for some stupid idiotic reason. Not that I particularly want to see on TV a female having sex with someone anyway; I'd prefer just to see her nude, though it's hard to be certain since all portrayals of sex on TV are disgusting for external reasons anyway. Where are the mistresses in the movies who have sex because they rightly love the deserving male they are having sex with? One could expect pornographers to be prudish if one didn't know better, because certainly they superfluosly belittle females who care greatly about real (clean)sexual pleasure (either their own or their mate's)--mistresses are never portrayed as moral.
 
 The kind of violence that bothers me is the kind which domineering males like to use to make those they dominate more afraid of them. Abusive types who like to dominate through physical violence have a need to make those they abuse think them more dangerous than they really are. Thus, these males like, for example, to take their girlfriends to mindless slasher movies starring murderers vaguely like themselves so their girlfriends will think not just that their boyfriends want to dominate them, but that under certain circumstances of disobedience they would enjoy killing them. This delusion if present in the girl can make the abuser's physical abuse more controlling, because obviously girls don't like to get killed. What happens on occasion is that the lies which the media makes to feed the wicked needs of thuggish males end up fooling the thuggish males themselves. On occasion a thug believes not only that he wants to dominate, but that also that he wants to kill, which is what makes most serial killers. Serial killers don't by nature enjoy killing, but because they are dumb they sometimes believe the lies that they encourage for the delusions of others, and so on occasion they come to believe that somehow they profit by killing people for no reason when in fact they are just likely to earn a death sentence.
 
 On the other hand, there is a great deal of frustration in society, and many people have violent cruel feelings under the surface because at some insane level they feel they are being forcibly abused and molested. This sort of mindless violence (e.g., females acting too cruel for insane reasons of excessive cleanliness) on TV doesn't really bother me--in fact, insane violence seems more insane the more one considers it, so looking at such violence in a way can calm one down by making you realize how it is basically silly. And it might scare abusive males some, which I suppose is all for the good.
Nallyo

I understand what you are saying, step314, but I disagree. While you may be older and more wise in the ways of the world, what about the impressionable young boys and girls in grade school? For Pete's sake, all of the studies (which I typically don't pay attention to but do find grains of truth in) show a rise in underage pregnancies, sex, drinking, violent crimes, and drug use. People tend to underestimate the power of the media, thinking that kids will not copy what they see. While in no way am I saying that violent video games lead to killing sprees, I worry more about the "realistic" shows that are on Network and Cable TV during primetime. While we may tell that they are fake and absolutely contrary to real life, kids believe what they are told because they are young and their minds are growing and assimilating all of the information they can.
Dante3315

Oh woah...look ... an "off" button...
 
 Duuude...
 
 Sweet...
Robbie

Oh woah...look ... an "off" button...
 
 Duuude...
 
 Sweet...

 
 Yah, totally. I mean, all those families watching the superbowl... they should have changed the channel during the half-time. I don't know what they're complaining about. And obviously, parents should just watch the t.v. all the time so they can turn it off when something raunchy comes on.
sundowner

Yah, totally. I mean, all those families watching the superbowl... they should have changed the channel during the half-time. I don't know what they're complaining about. And obviously, parents should just watch the t.v. all the time so they can turn it off when something raunchy comes on.

 
 The halftime show was a fluke, this is not an everyday occurance. It was deliberate and deplorable. It deserved to be fined. Shows like NYPD Blue et all...are a different story. Some even have warnings at the start of their show stating that some of the content may be objectionable to some. I totally agree....use the damn on/off switch. I happen to like shows like this. If you take it off the air, I can't enjoy it anymore. If you turn it off, you don't have to see it. Or better yet, change the channel. There is bound to be something on you find enjoyable and wholesome. Personally, I can't stand the "christian" networks, nor the home shopping networks...so I don't watch them. As far as protecting our children from "morally questionable" television, that is the sole responsibility of the parents. Superbowl aside, (again...not a relevant example) any RESPONSIBLE parent should be concerned with what their children are watching...let's face it...some of the programming is not meant for children. TV's now have channel blocking technology that can allow parents to block certain channels...many TV's can even be deactivated to all channels unless you enter a code for them. If a parent is that concerned, they need to explore this technology. (I still think the on/off button is the best answer...low tech rules). Network, cable, whatever...it is all one thing...an entertainment venue. You may not find some of it entertaining or worthwhile programming, but I might. If people cannot control what their children are watching on television, they have bigger problems than some "offensive" programs.
Dante3315

You're watching a sport that involves knocking hte **** out of each other on a regular basis. The sponsors are various beer companies, viagra, and comercials that involve numerous sexual innuendoes and more skin than you saw on Jackson. 
 The half-time lead up to the incident involved scantily clad dancers writhing onstage (so much so that the cameras cut away), an artist wearing the American flag as a poncho, (which violates Title 4, Chapter 1, Sec. 8 of US Code) amongst other things.
 
 What did you really expect? Where was the outrage? It was the most TiVo'd, most searched for video clip ever. And you see diddly anyway. 
 
 A testament to hypocrisy.
 
 This is what you choose to whine about?
Phunting

Jeez did you guys really get upset about that? I still can't believe the fuss being made over nothing.
 
 I'd hate to think that my children might ever see a woman's nipple, now that's so un-natural and sickening that it might just turn them into drooling perverts in an instant. emoticon_rolleyes
 
 In fact I can't believe you guys have such harsh restrictions on your telly, not even allowing nudity even late at night except on cable. Can't say I gonna enjoy such daft restrictions when I move back to the states.
Robbie

Well, I concede that sundowner has some good points. 
 
 So, Phunting, Dante, do you think that there should be no restrictions?
Phunting

No not at all, of course that would be irresponsible.
 
 I'm not really sure on how censorship works in the states. But on british non-cable telly mild swearing/violence is allowed past 6; medium swearing/violence, mild sex/drug use past 9; and strong swearing/violence/sex/full nudity past about 10.30 or 11.
 
 Those aren't the official times, just roughly what I've noticed from watching over the years.
 
 Now I think that's about right, and it appears to work. We are 'degenerating' no faster than you are after all.
Robbie

So you don't disagree with censorship on principal, only in degree. 
 
 In the half-time case it was before 9:00, the entire nation was watching (pretty much) which included a lot of families, so I think that would be a pretty flagrant violation in Britian as well. Actually I'm not sure how censorship works in the US either. It seems to be partially arbitrary.
Phunting

In the half-time case it was before 9:00, the entire nation was watching (pretty much) which included a lot of families, so I think that would be a pretty flagrant violation in Britian as well.

 I don't think it would have been, it was only a breast. It wouldn't have been a problem, especially as it was an 'accident', in fact it was shown uncensored on the news.
 
 From the BBC's internet news coverage of it:
 
 
"I know many people in other countries are scratching their heads and thinking 'What in the world is the big fuss over there?'," said Robert Thompson, director of the Centre for the Study of Popular Television at Syracuse University. 
 
 "But this country takes exposed breasts very, very seriously. We get very exercised about such things." 
 
 There is no denying the level of public fury. Within minutes of the Super Bowl half time performance, the internet was abuzz with angry chatter and phone lines to CBS's New York headquarters were jammed. 
 
 "That was the most disgusting thing that I have ever seen at a sports spectacle," said baseball coach Tommy Lasorda in Los Angeles. 
 
 "They just absolutely ruined the fact that it was one of the greatest Super Bowl games that I have ever seen." 
 
 But on a scale of terrible things that happen in public, is a fleetingly bare breast so terrible?...
 
 The telecast also featured sexed-up commercials for beer, an advert starring a flatulent horse and others for erectile dysfunction drugs. 
 
 But, apparently, they do not compare with the impact of an exposed body part. 
 
 "Maybe when we left the old country we somehow froze certain attitudes," explained Mr Thompson. 
 
 "While other attitudes began to evolve elsewhere we held to many of them very carefully. There is this paradoxical part of the American character where we are simultaneously arguably the most obsessed about sex of anybody else in the entire planet and at the same time the most uptight about it." 

 Quite
jim's trucking

Yah, totally. I mean, all those families watching the superbowl... they should have changed the channel during the half-time. I don't know what they're complaining about. And obviously, parents should just watch the t.v. all the time so they can turn it off when something raunchy comes on.

 
 How ridiculous can thoughts be? Families were sitting around the TV watching a football game. What warning do you suppose they had that the show would turn south as it did?
 
 There's plenty of sex and soft porn available on cable channels where one knows what one is getting into. This does not excuse it on the public broadcast channels.
 
 Your arguments that "there's an off-button" and that...
 
 
 Yah, totally. I mean, all those families watching the superbowl... they should have changed the channel during the half-time. I don't know what they're complaining about. And obviously, parents should just watch the t.v. all the time so they can turn it off when something raunchy comes on. 

 
 are like saying that if I'm in a theater, watching a play...someone urinates on the floor beside me, I can always move to another seat or another theater.
 
 You are free to watch what you want on the pay channels...free TV should be void of smut and trash such as was on the Superbowl Halftime show.
 
 ...and it doesn't take a bible thumping religious zealot to say that. I'm all for your freedom to watch what you please. Just don't try to force ludeness on the whole population. You want porn, pay for it and keep it to yourself!
jim's trucking

No not at all, of course that would be irresponsible.
 
 I'm not really sure on how censorship works in the states. But on british non-cable telly mild swearing/violence is allowed past 6; medium swearing/violence, mild sex/drug use past 9; and strong swearing/violence/sex/full nudity past about 10.30 or 11.
 
 Those aren't the official times, just roughly what I've noticed from watching over the years.
 
 Now I think that's about right, and it appears to work. We are 'degenerating' no faster than you are after all.

 
 Censorship has changed over the years. When Elvis first appeared on Ed Sullivan, they wouldn't allow any camera shots from the waist down; when Gone With the Wind was being filmed, the censors consternated over Rhett Butler's line, "Frankly, ...I don't give a damn."
 
 Plainly, this Victorian censorship has disappeared, as it should have. emoticon_xhoho 
 
 There still has be a line between what's allowed on public TV and what's allowed on pay TV. Janet Jackson's exposure didn't belong in the show. Neither did Kid Rock's poncho. Neither did any of the crotch holding performers. The whole show might have fit well on MTV, but was inappropriate from end to end for the Superbowl.
Robbie

How ridiculous can thoughts be? Families were sitting around the TV watching a football game. What warning do you suppose they had that the show would turn south as it did?...
 
 are like saying that if I'm in a theater, watching a play...someone urinates on the floor beside me, I can always move to another seat or another theater.
 
 You are free to watch what you want on the pay channels...free TV should be void of smut and trash such as was on the Superbowl Halftime show.
 
 ...and it doesn't take a bible thumping religious zealot to say that. I'm all for your freedom to watch what you please. Just don't try to force ludeness on the whole population. You want porn, pay for it and keep it to yourself!

 
 I compeletly agree. I was parodying people who say that you can just change the channel. I guess it sounded too much like what they really say! Kids can't be watched all the time, and I think it is accepted by all that porn and hardcore violence aren't good for kids. Saying you should just change the channel on public TV is like saying you should drive a different route to school if you don't wan't your kids seeing the same stuff on a billboard.
Phunting

There still has be a line between what's allowed on public TV and what's allowed on pay TV. Janet Jackson's exposure didn't belong in the show. Neither did Kid Rock's poncho. Neither did any of the crotch holding performers. The whole show might have fit well on MTV, but was inappropriate from end to end for the Superbowl.

 But that is a question of what is appropriate for a sporting event, not what should be allowed on the television.
 
 Oh and what about Kid Rock's poncho? I'm guessing a poncho is a type of raincoat over there as well?
Robbie

I think the distinction is between cable and public TV. FYI, apparently cable providers are now offering substantial filtering options, even for free, in the U.S. now.
 
 A poncho is a rain coat here in Canada, too. Kid Rock was basically draped in a flag. Apparently it violates some law.
Phunting

A poncho is a rain coat here in Canada, too. Kid Rock was basically draped in a flag. Apparently it violates some law.

 Wearing a flag is against the law? Whatever happened to freedom of expression?
jim's trucking

But that is a question of what is appropriate for a sporting event, not what should be allowed on the television.
 
 

 
 As the vast multitudes know, the Super Bowl is the most widely televised single sporting event ever. That's why the commercial time is so expensive and that's why it is chosen to debut new commercials. Buyers know the audience will be huge.
 
 The halftime show would not have been appropriate even if there were no cameras. Stuff like that does not belong at a football game.
 
 Maybe it was suitable for a concert or an MTV show where people know what to expect and are willing to pay for it, but it was not in any way appropriate for where it was done.
 
 ...and Janet Jackson can say all she wants about how it was an accident...that's bullchips. You can easily tell by her immediate reaction that it was planned. What a cheap trick.
 
 Here's to public decency! emoticon_xhoho
Robbie

Wearing a flag is against the law? Whatever happened to freedom of expression?

 
 The 9th post on the 1st page (by Dante) has a link to the laws in question. Its interesting... very detailed.
Phunting

The 9th post on the 1st page (by Dante) has a link to the laws in question. Its interesting... very detailed.

 Interesting indeed. Is it law? Or just recommended ways of treating the flag with 'respect'?
 
 If it is law I find that very concerning indeed...

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  POLL: Your opinion about "filth" on radio and TV and why?
